proj_bullets: Category==Masterplanning | Ecodesign | Smart city==Client==Shanghai urban design bureau==Status==Competition Entry | Published in Masterplanning the Future 2012==Year==2012
proj_descr:
The project is a masterplanning proposal for an idea based design competition. The site is at the Suzhou creek of Jingan District at Shanghai, China, This area is currently under rapid development with projects ranging from mixed use to high end residential towers (100m to 150m). The competition guidelines expected us to provide a futuristic riverfront development proposal utilising sustainable and eco-friendly design strategies. We proposed a green masterplan which focuses on replenishing lost urban green space owing to rampant construction and environmental waste.

The program of the masterplan comprises of premium office towers, mid-rise studio apartments, high-end residential apartments along with commercial retail streets and shopping malls. Adding to these, our design proposal addressess how the green fabric of the city can be revitalised and improvised. We proposed to construct high-rise buildings with lower built foot print that minimizes ground cover dilapidation. The precious ground area can be used as green gardens. Also, vertically we allowed scooping pockets of built spaces and replacing with sky gardens, which further enhances the concept of eco green city in the middle of a metropolis like Shanghai. In the 21st century where technology almost commands every aspect of life, we let technology also control the urban fabric and the quality of the built envrionment. Thereby, the proposal for the masterplan, exemplified the use of green algae as a means to reproduce solar energy upon reaction with sunlight. These green algae facade panels were embedded on to the building facade systems. These systems also termed as photo bio-reactors, apart from producing energy also minimizes the net carbon footprint of the neighborhood.

proj_bullets: Category==Transportation | Sustainable Design==Client==Insdag (INSTITUTE OF NATIONAL STEEL DEVLOPMENT AND GROWTH)==Status==Ranked 2nd prize in a competition==Year==2006==Team==With Souporni Paul, JU, India
proj_descr:
Project was to design a world class railway station with state of the art facilities in a small town in Rajasthan, India. The station was expected to accomodate two platforms of size 60m each. We studied the hot and dry climate of Rajasthan. We designed the station shed, with an efficient structural system capable to handle violent sandstorms, a frequently occuring natural phenomena in the desert climate of the site. As the design was amid sand dunes, we formulated the concept from the genesis of sand dunes. The sheds' form was driven by aerodynamic factors of the wind. Rain water harvesting methods were deployed to address water scarcity. The rain water harvesting tank also helped in cooling the station. Efficient ventillation was proposed by the placement of computer controlled vents on the glass roof. Station waiting areas and cafes were placed underground to reduce solar heating due to the hot and dry weather.

First time ever separate transportation of luggages & passengers were provided. Separate conveyor belt & freight elevator system helped this process. Roof vents on the main shed added day lighting & helped transfer hot air out & cool air inside. The floor slabs were supported with regular perforated cellular beams, with fire insulation. These perforations saved material & rendered the structure light. They rested on articulated lattice portal structure spanning 30m over the platforms. The aerodynamic roof rested on 5 equally spaced aluminium coated tree columns. This roof is built with the help of mero space frames which rested upon circular hollow sectioned secondary beams and I-section primary beams.

proj_bullets: Category==School | Education | Smart learning==Client==Sejong National Model City Middle and High School, South Korea==Status==Design Entry==Year==2021
proj_descr:
Equinox is a novel learning platform that invites people in a new urban district to be part of an educational revolution. In this proposal we provide a design concept for the middle school, while a high school is provided as a concept schematic, that will follow similar design guidelines. Our design is principally based on three main concepts further described below:

Spatial variety: Different people learn in different conditions. Conventional learning spaces are too rigid and fixed which misses the flexibility needed to allow for conducive conditions that can encourage students to learn new knowledge in their most comfortable space. In this design, we ensure that we provide a diverse array of spaces that can accommodate the varied needs of students. In addition, we provide flexible semi-open (with nature) spaces that encourage students to collaborate and invent to make new technology, new design or new art. Every space is both digitally and physically connected using means such as large displays, drones, touch screen surface displays etc.

Connectedness: The second concept of this design is inside out connectedness to the city and the neighboring urban fabric. We think education is not only for enrolled students but also for the larger community of which the school is a distinct participant. The design of the school invites people to participate in the learning process by creating public spaces such as public library, exhibition galleries, AR-VR Tech Media Tower that may exhibit students work. These spaces can provide specially designed classes to people in diverse topics such as AI, mobile technology, nanotechnology, calligraphy etc.

Eco-adaptable: While our design looks into the future with the state of the art technology, it embraces the historical learnings humans have learned. In that spirit, while the shape and form of the design is unconventional and futuristic, the building materials are eco friendly, sustainable and eco-adaptable. We use stone, wood, and eco-friendly glazings'. In addition, we minimize the glazed area to guard against direct glaring sunlight that minimizes the energy cost of the building.

proj_bullets: Category==Furniture | Public Art | Social Interaction==Client==A8 Design Center, China==Status==Design Entry==Year==2021
proj_descr:
Pod is a novel public seating arrangement in a post COVID-19 world. The design encourages safe and responsible social distancing but at the same time provides ample opportunity to close friends or families (living in the same house or apartment) to sit and stay closer in a public space. Each Pod is a semi covered seating of dimension 1400 mm by 1400 mm (height 1500 mm) allowing upto two adults to sit together in the same Pod. In addition, these units are movable, meaning users can rotate their orientation to face to or away from another Pod (person sitting next to them). These Pods are installed on a metal channel or track, on which these can be further pushed around to reposition their location. This is designed to allow people to keep separation with one another or stay close to their family members. The track ensures the public seating is not vandalized or stolen, or not misplaced, creating clutter in the city.

Pods are built with sustainable galvanized steel as a single pivoting structural post. The covering of the Pod can either be built with wood or 3D printed ceramics with customized colors. These colored units can add diversity and positivity to any public space where they are placed. Besides, the surfacing is designed to be smooth and self-cleaning without any nooks and cranny, thus removing the need to frequently clean these units.

Furthermore, these units can be solar powered and can be equipped with USB chargers with bluetooth connections to allow users to sit and work for longer durations. Each Pod unit comes with storage spaces that may allow parents (can store baby changing equipments) and workers (can store laptop bags) to sit comfortably with peace.

proj_bullets: Category==High-rise | Mixed-use | Air cleaner==Client==CTBUH==Status==Design Entry==Year==2016
proj_descr:
PROBLEM

Air pollution in Asia is a problem that needs immediate human intervention. As a case study site, the city of Beijing in China is chosen where air pollution level is so high that at least one third of the countrys' population gets badly effected causing as many as 1.6 million peoples' death. According to Greenpeace, China's air pollution puts public health at risk every day because of the presence of minuscule particles known as PM2.5. These are more prone to carrying a variety of toxic heavy metals, acid oxides, organic pollutants, and other chemicals, as well as micro-organisms such as bacteria and viruses in the air. The proposed high rise tower 'E- PURIFY' is a step towards making a better tomorrow by not only manifesting the building as an urban air cleaning agent but also as a way to bring human beings closer to nature by imbibing healthier and sustainable lifestyle.

ENVIRONMENT

Pollution control : The proposed high rise structure is designed as a twin tower, connected on the top as an iconic gateway forming a landmark impression to the visitor, thereby attracting more people to the site. The 698m tower is wrapped with a porous screen facade screen (225 000 sq m area) built with Titanium Dioxide. As air interacts with it, UV-light-activated free radicals destroy any existing pollutants cleaning the neighboring air substantially. The form of the tower is aerodynamically designed to aid flow of air on the tower to maximize volume of air cleaned per day. The exterior walls of the facade are angled inside to minimize wind load on the tower. The porosity of the screen is higher on the lower levels of the tower and lower on the upper levels of the tower to optimize adequate interior daylighting. A vertical green park is provided which aids cleaning the air further by removing a large amount of carbon and dust particles from the environment. In addition, this green cover adds oxygen, provides acoustic buffer and reduces urban heat island effect. The tower is built from cross laminated timber, an engineered wood consisting of multiple timber sections along with reinforced steel. This reduces the embodied energy use in the project by 70-80%. Also as timber is recyclable, the lost timber from trees can be regrown. Timber construction speeds up the construction time manifolds and provides a much refined high quality spatial experience.

Energy Production: The vertical green park has over 20000 sq.m. size of algae photo bio reactors which interacts with the sun rays and the carbon dioxide from the environment. The resulting biomass is burnt to provide electricity and heat to the tower. While conventionally PV cells are used to provide energy, the process to manufacture these cells is expensive and is extremely polluting to the nature. The technology embedded on the vertical green park, collects light and uses it to grow Algae within the bio reactors. The grown algae is taken to a combustion chamber to form biomass which is then converted to electricity or heat. The upper levels of the tower also relies on wind turbines to generate energy.

CONTEXT AND USE

The proposed development is approx. 1 million sq.m. size entertainment district positioned, very close to Sanlitun area in Beijing which is widely popular for recreational uses. The towers' predominant uses are restaurants, retails, shopping areas, exhibition galleries, luxury hotels and health resorts. Other uses include creative offices for entertainment industry including artists' studio and maker spaces. Considering the close proximity of the site to the bustling Sanlitun district, newly built Phoenix Media Center, Chaoyang park and the Chaoyang Park Plaza, it will get the much needed footfall for an extended vertical recreational district which stays active 18 hours of the day. One of the innovative functions of the tower is a vertical green park, which is a space to hang out with friends, walk your dog, workout, yoga, play with animals or birds, grow your own vegetables and learn about nature. Essentially, it brings people closer to the nature and increases bio diversity in the city.

proj_bullets: Category==Mobile pods | Smart neighborhood | Future Vision==Client==Suqian City Municipality, China==Status==Design Entry==Year==2018
proj_descr:
CONCEPT : Smart Mobile Pod Neighborhood

The site given was at the scenic and famous Suqian city's Luoma lake in in Jiangsu, China. Originally tourists needed to walk or explore the vast area of the surrounding area of the lake by foot, boat, circulators etc. Hotel/ hospitality services close to the park often endanger biodiversity and essence of the nature to support peoples' tourism needs. Our idea was a fusion of improved e-commerce and hospitality services. We proposed PODISTLE - I , mobile pods/tents that would blend with the natural surrounding, and have mobility within a defined natural precincts. Guests could hire these mobile pods on hourly, daily or even monthly basis. All services (like food, water, dry cleaning etc.) could be delivered to the pods through e-commerce services that would allow guests to live and explore nature at any time of the day without worrying about their daily chores. The design of the pods was kept minimal (starting from a sphere geometry, minimal volume/ area) to allow visitors to enjoy the natural surrounding at its best. The pod was envisioned to allow visitors to access land and water bodies within public precincts.

Guests could carry Podistle around the lake, to enjoy the pristine beautiful nature and at the same time, experience diverse views/sites near the lake. The lake had many nodes around it, given its strategic location, for example, the Zhangshan Forest Park, Yanghetian Ecological Garden, Yaowan Ancient Town etc. This provided an oppportunity for many pod stations which can allow people to board the pod and spend time on the lake and visit all the adjoining locations. Its a new hotel business model where site seeing and staying was facilitated at the same time.

The design was equipped with a 8000 sqft area of photovoltaic sheet, which was strategically oriented to maximise solar gain and generate energy. It had controllable vertical rust resistant metal fins, allowing variable shading to augment diffused daylighting to the interior. Many Podistile together, created a smart network with shared cloud-based infrastructure to faciliate hassle-free interaction and communication between guests. They were augmented with mobile and desktop apps encouraging users to interact and mingle with their neighbors on the lake.

proj_descr:
Project is the design of high-rise luxury residences in the scenic area of Ninghai mountain near Ningbo city China. There are five 250m towers each housing suites and room units from studio to 4 bedroom suites. The towers are designed using on environmentally sound design concepts such as incorporating trombe wall, lowering glazed surfaces, light sheves and louver systems, green terracing and inteligent building orientation in the site. The ground floor accomodates banquet halls, coffee shops, restaurants, shopping arena and old age compact quarters.

Energy Conservation methods used include trombe wall, low e-glazing, sustainable wood, planters and roof terracing, louvers & light sheves. The towers are placed on the Ninghai mountain next to an artificial lake and designed keeping the sun path in mind. Thereby the facade/skin of the tower is subdivided into north and south facade, and respective treatment is provided to protect the interior spaces. For example, the south side facade reflects horizontal louver and aluminium light shelf system to reflect light deep inside.The north facade comprises of clear glass along with a projected balcony. The railing of the balcony lowers down to a planter box on the south facade to screen the direct summer sun light. A 12 inch thick trombe wall system is located on the south west location, thereby tapping maximum winter heat during day, which could be used for energy generation for the tower. The trombe wall also contains a horizontal shading cover for high angle summer sun, when excessive heat is not needed. The grasshopper program screenshots shows the formation of the tower shape from a simple square. Generative design approach is utilised to search for an optimal tower shape with the aforementioned design guidelines and the geometrical form of the tower.

proj_bullets: Category==Graphic Arts | Furniture design | Branding==Client==Houston Post Office, USA==Status==Design Entry==Year==2020
proj_descr:
Recent unfortunate environmental calamities such as COVID-19, Australian wildfires, Houston flooding, shows that many human endeavors (e.g., drastic deforestation, extreme air pollution, the rampant killing of animals, etc.) have created a long-lasting dent to the natural system of the world. In this design challenge, we were motivated to educate and spread awareness of the dire seriousness of this problem and the need to create a change; a change where each one of us 'can' and 'need' to contribute.

POST Houston, the Houston's Theatre District, offers a brilliant opportunity for people to convene and connect in its new cultural and commercial hub in downtown Houston. This space is expected to be an inspiring platform for people to meet for various activities such as recreation, cultural events, business meetups, 'do it yourself' activities, discussions, and demos, etc. Such a setting provides an excellent opportunity to convey to a large audience the change our planet is going through by showing visual narratives that can spread awareness and knowledge. We present ACT-ON, a graphic design theme laid on eight monolithic steel furniture masses, that are part of a Superfurniture series. These graphic boards are carefully designed to visually show a scenario that posits, how the current world may look like in the near future, or how we may participate in preventing further harm to the environment. In this design scheme, we show a few Graphic Illustrations as representative samples that can be laid on these Superfurnitures. These graphic boards may have different tilings on the furniture based on its shape, configuration, and size. The boards can be mixed together to use on a piece of single furniture, as shown in the renderings. Individually these boards are designed to be of 3m by 1m in dimension but can be custom-produced to fit any future from the Superfurniture series.

Our visual design reflects scenarios caused by the unexpected change in the climate, such as global warming causing the rise of sea waters, massive deforestation due to fast-paced urbanization causing animals to lose home and spaces to thrive. Our design theme presents these stunning visuals with vibrant colors and thought-provoking slogans to encourage people to make sense of the visuals, understand the motivation, and engage in a public discussion with people they connect.

proj_bullets: Category==Product Design | AR Concept | Smart City==Client==Handan, China==Status==Design Entry==Year==2020
proj_descr:
Handan, China is a historic city with a rich heritage and culture (e.g., diverse food, history, art, and crafts work, etc.) that presents a wide array of majestic spatial experiences. However, to address the diverse needs of people and to serve the ever-growing urban population, Handans' spatial complexity grows. This renders its urban spaces difficult for people to keep track of, and navigate without any external aid such as Baidu or Bing maps, etc. This problem becomes even more serious, (1) when someone new is visiting the city, (2) for older adults or children or (3) even for regular people who go to see new places. One of the major outcomes of cities' rapid growth is that people struggle to find ways to their desired destination. Another common problem that people face is the inability to interact and collaborate with others. Often people are engaged with their mobile devices or spend time alone. Public interaction and exchange of ideas caters to the healthy growth of the citizens of a city, which, unfortunately, is missing as we modernize human civilization.

To solve these urban problems, we present vennAR, an augmented reality (AR) based immersive experience. We select Plot 6, Congtai Square, as our site in the city. Our design 'vennAR' is a 1600mm x 600mm x 1900mm (length, width, and height) vending machine for AR experience. This machine allows users to borrow or rent AR glasses using their Wechat QR codes. VennAR is designed to present four touch-based ultra-HD screens to users (two main, and two side screens). Users can touch to browse the internet to search for places to eat, drink, entertain, or visit interesting events in the city. With the preliminary knowledge of where to go and how to navigate, users can then checkout an AR glass. This glass helps them to navigate across the city aided by an immersive mixed-reality experience and with hand gestures as input to their interactions. With vennAR, we present one device and one database bsed user experience, which means users dont need their phone. All data sources are unified and visualized on the canvas of the 3D world of Handan.

Apart from navigation/way-finding, users can also use vennAR to interact and engage with other people in the city. For example, they can participate in AR games playable at any plaza or any open outdoor public space by interacting with nearby users. Similarly, they can go for shared boat rides in the nearby Congtai park, where they can experience never seen before immersive experience that is visually stimulating, creative, and engaging. People using vennAR would love to spend extended time in the outdoor urban space, thereby enriching and activating the public realm. With this project proposal, we intend to grant users a unified data source and a single device (AR glass) based user experience that lets them fluidly interact, communicate, and find places of interest across the majestic city of Handan, China.

proj_bullets: Category==Ecological Design | Residences | Sustainable Construction==Client==Kolkata, India==Status==Thesis Project==Year==2008
proj_descr:
The research project outlines novel methodologies adapted to re-design an existing apartment building in Salt Lake, Kolkata, India, to enhance its indoor comfort level, in terms of daylighting, indoor ventilation, and thermal comfort. For the same, first an in-depth study was conducted of an existing apartment, which highlighted areas of improvements in terms of environmental performance. Some of the points, that we learned are:

1. Extremely dark indoor spaces in the service areas and living areas of all the four apartments in the building in each floor.

2. South facing rooms faced suns glare most of the day and afternoons.

3. North facing rooms were exceptionally cold during winters due to lack of sunshine and heating.

4. Inappropriate location of windows on the south and west end of the building, obstructed the possibility of cross ventilation and thus incoming wind could not be channelized to other parts of the apartment.

5. West facing wall faced extreme solar radiation and thus enabled uncomfortable indoor spaces adjoining it.

Motivated to resolve some of these existing issues, novel computational methods were employed to device sustainable solutions. Using computational simulation tools and digital three dimensional modeling techniques, the project validaes the design interventions' effectiveness in improving indoor daylighting, ventilation levels, and thermal comfort.

proj_bullets: Category==Sculpture | Energy generator | Urban Art==Client==Land Art Generator==Status==Design Entry==Year==2014
proj_descr:
A design proposal of an hour glass inspired sculpture at Copenhagen, Denmark, that not only adds to the urban spatial quality, but also exemplifies novel means to generate energy. On site, we placed a series of hour glasses, with a pedestrian walkway over the existing waterbody, to create a majestic experience for visitors.

VAWT, Fish Scoop Effect Tech:
Each hour glass accomodates a Vertical axis Wind turbine (also called VAWT, Darrieus type). These Vawt turbines are capable to generate electricity from the wind energy on-site, which is on average 6m/s. Each of these units are tall enough to generate 2285820 kWh from 8 turbines annually, enough to run 650 homes. VAWT has many advantages over horizontal axis turbines, including compactness, cheaper cost, and easier to install. A recent study by The Caltech Field Laboratory for Optimized Wind Energy (FLOWE) found that as VAWTs can be placed closer together, they're capable of generating ten times as much energy per square meter than horizontal axis turbines. The study also found that having each VAWT spin in the opposite direction of its neighbor allowed them to spin faster because the opposing spins reduced the drag on each turbine, which upped their efficiency even more.

SOLAR DESALINATION, solar furnace:
Adding to the above in each of the hour glass theres' a modified solar furnace installed at the bottom part of the sculpture. Unlike conventional solar furnace systems, we proposed to use recycled plastic-based (with much lower embodied energy) Fresnel lens (7m in diameter) at 30m height from ground to boil water in the base. This Fresnel lens reduces the amount of material required compared to a conventional lens by dividing the lens into a set of concentric annular sections.

PV CELL TECHNOLOGY, integrated with Rawlemon Sphere's:
From research, it looks like Copenhagen has great potential of PV Cell technology. But since our sculptural art form is resonating with each others' form in the group, especially the orientation of the top of the hour glass is angled at different degrees for each system, they do not allow enough leverage to harness efficient solar radiation. Furthermore, we captured solar energy by deploying a Rawlemon sphere, 6m in diameter on top of the structure, that housed PV cells on its surface.

proj_bullets: Category==Master plan | Place making | Urban design==Client==With VAST LLC, Shanghai, China==Status==Design Development==Year==2012
proj_descr:
Urban plan proposal for Shanghai's South Bund District in China. The design proposal is the redevelopment of the old port area in south bund district of Shanghai and its due urban connectivity to the adjoining spaces, which currently is in bits and pieces. It fails to create any wholesome urban space for Shanghai. Unlike today, this old port in Shanghai was used to be in service for business and merchandize activities in yester years. So the project intended to recreate business and commercial value to the port district. At the same time it aspired to percolate green networks in the urban space. In such a model, built forms can be positioned around this innovative green channel for mobility.

With due considerations to all associated infrastructures & architectural factor, an elevated plaza cum green connection is proposed to connect all the neighboring urban spaces with this developed region. This green corridor is a continuous urban space ( connected to all the surrounding built forms) which would be used both to inhabit and to connect neighborhoods to one another, by employing diverse & interesting public functions over it.

Image Source, Vast LLC, China.

proj_bullets: Category==Utopian concept | Habitat in Moon | Futuristic Vision==Client==With W2 Architects, China==Status==Design Entry==Year==2011
proj_descr:
The project is a conceptualization of possibility of human habitat in moon, in impending future. The idea is to create an egg shaped spatial environment conducive to human life. Just like an egg, which protects its yolk with the strong protective padding albumen, our design protects the inside by a strong thermal and environmentally protective titanium skin outside.

The interior of the structure comprises of an outer ellicoidal pathway, inhabiting urban farming alongwith futuristic high speed vertical transportation. This ellicoidal pathway is connected with the urban space of the center which is the yolk. The city in the yolk space grows like a cell, orienting its logistics, which was simulated using a cellular automata algorithm. These cells would be pre-fabricated modular units, imported from earth. The city within would be allowed to grow inside while human habitation gradually sprawls and settles in Moon.

Our vision for this futuristic city in moon, imagines that as one egg-shaped structure finishes the other one starts to grow. The design of the urban city inside is kept within a peripheral shell of urban vegetation, parks and green land on the external ellicoidal path. This sheild acts as a buffer zone where people from the city can go and interact with the nature. An algae screen was proposed to be installed which interacts with the sun to form hydrogen which in turn helps to produce energy for the inhabitants for the city.

proj_awards_title: Winner of the 3rd prize at the INSDAG National Design Competition, India
proj_bullets: Category==Trade fair pavillion | Exhibition galleries | Public spaces==Client==Insdag, India==Status==Ranked 3rd prize==Year==2006==Team==With Souporni Paul, Sourav Ray, JU, India
proj_descr:
Project was to design a trade fair complex consisting of air conditioned (AC) and non air conditioned (non AC) exhibition halls and galleries. Our concept was to place the AC & non AC exhibition halls into separate zones, connected via an urban plaza. The AC building, was designed by placing the floor plates of the exhibition galleries offset from one another. This was a novel approach in trade fair exhibition facilities as conventionally steel buildings of such programs are designed using a monotonous grid type arrangement, one floor placed above another. This design exemplified the extensive power of steel as a structural material with structural spans covering as long as 120m in length. The non AC halls were semi-open steel meshes, covered by FRP covering, placed on a contoured land, with landscape elements built with stainless steel. These included, lamp posts, signages, public seatings & display kiosks.

The cantilevered floor arrangment was made possible by a structural system inspired from suspension bridges (spanning as long as 80m). Further, the ground space that was left open (due to the suspended floors), was utilised by placing fire water reservoir, loading/unloading bay & other services. Steel landscape features such as lights, seatings etc. broke the monotony and further emphasized the power of steel as a construction and a decorative material.

The site included an old historic airport area, new central business district (CBD) and the old Shanxi river. Our design highlights a landmark 500m tower, green bridge, facade re-design of a set of urban blocks near the CBD region. Our proposal aligned with the Leed Neighborhod Development Program's design guidelines. The proposed urban model recommended the old airport to be re-used as a recreational and gathering space for general public.

The design of the landmark 500m tower was conceptualized from the famous plum blossom of the city Nanjing. The five fingered petals were replicated as floor space while the spaces in betwen the petals were formulated as green space. The idea was to succesfully integrate urban space and green vegetation in one built environment. The tower design included wind mills on its south-east and north-east facade, and a roof-top green house observatory. The landmark tower connected with the green bridge providing access to the river and the adjoining landscaped urban farming area. The bridge had undulating pathways and a soft covering of grass, that created spatial vareity and mitigated urban heat island effect in the neighboring region.

proj_bullets: Category==Canal redevelopment | Urban design==Client==Kolkata, India==Status==Ranked top 8 best designs nationally==Year==2008
proj_descr:
This is a design competition entry for a water canal redevelopment proposal in the city of Kolkata, India. The present state of the canal needed urgent intervention interms of cleaning and maintainence, as waste water from the surrounding neighborhoods blocked the water flow. Noteworthy to mention that there is a metro corridor running right over the canal, thus the canal water is interevened by structural columns of the metro bridge. Our design proposal retrofits the canal into a public place where people can gather to meet, interact or rest. Furthermore, we proposed to redevlope the canal into a rainwater catchment area. The below grade space of the canal is proposed to be used by installing on-site water treatment plants, which essentially would cleanse the dry waster water and rain water falling over the canal. This treated water can be re channelized into the neighboring housing settlements for their daily use.

Adding to the water treatment, our proposal also modeled a mid-level urban corridor over the canal and under the metro corridor directly hanging from the metro bridge. This mid-level corridor was expected to be a place of leisure and urban rejoice for the city. This area could be used for cafes and open seating wherein people can sit and relax.

The parametric facade design of the tower was inspired from the honeycomb pattern system. Rhino 3D and Python scripts were used to modulate the pattern system to control for optimized daylight levels. Furthermore, Ecotects' Radiance plugin was utilised to calculate incident lux level per floor. To help optimize construction cost six types of window systems were used, ranging from size 2200mm dia to 3000mm diameter over all the facade skin.

proj_bullets: Category==Hotel | Retail | Dynamic Facade==Client==With W2 Architects, China==Status==Design Proposal==Year==2010
proj_descr:
The project is a re-design of an existing hotel into a 100m tall tower comprising of Hotel and Office spaces in collaboration with W2 Architects, China. The form of the tower is generated by an algorithm which is driven by sun orientation and local climatological data. Inspired from natural pattern system found in animals, the building facade responds with the environment to generate optimized performance and aesthetics. The north facade remains more uniform through out considering uniform diffuse sun radiation in the north.

The site is studied in Ecotect and Grasshopper program to understand sun orientation and shadow effects throughout the day and the year. Grounded on weather data, the facade is designed so that the panels always make an optimal angle with the sun , to provide minimal sun radiation inside the building , which reduces building energy loads. Solar insolation is maximum when the sun is directly facing the facade. So, the panels are inclined in a way so that reduces incident solar insolation.

proj_descr:

We conceived the notion of a Womb, the ultimate genesis of human form. Architecturally, womb's shape is translated into a spheroidal form that opimizes energy consumption, and material usage while providing adequate space for comfortable living.

Other advanced techniques used include computer controlled photo voltaic cells, openable roof vents, rain water harvesting, air shafts, and waste water disposal systems. With global warming, and rising water levels, we envisaged by 2035 living on water would not be optional. We modeled the form of the building to be able to adapt both in land and water, owing to its shape being buoyant in nature. Each sustainable unit will be available with optional plans/configurations which join up to form many configurations inhabiting different number and types of dwellers.

proj_bullets: Category==Generative Design | Space plan automation | Automated space planning==Client==Autodesk, USA==Status==Autodesk Dynamo plugin written==Year==2016
proj_descr:
Design exploration in architectural space planning is often constrained by tight deadlines and a need to apply necessary expertise at the right time. We hypothesize that a system that can computationally generate vast numbers of design options, respect project constraints, and analyze for client goals, can assist the design team and client to make better decisions. This project explains a research venture built from insights into space planning from senior planners, architects, and experts in the field, coupled with algorithms for evolutionary systems and computational geometry, to develop an automated computational framework that enables rapid generation and analysis of space plan layouts.

Space plan generator is a computational framework (available as an Autodesk Dynamo Plugin) that automatically generates hundreds of design options from inputs typically provided by an architect, including a site outline and program document with desired spaces, areas, quantities, and adjacencies to be satisfied. We envision that this workflow can clarify project goals early in the design process, save time, enable better resource allocation, and assist key stakeholders to make informed decisions and deliver better designs. Further, the system is tested on a case study healthcare design project with set goals and objectives.

proj_bullets: Category==Healthcare planning | Design Automation | Optimization| Retail==Client==With Dr. John Haymakers' Studio at Georgia Tech, USA==Status==Masters group project==Year==2015
proj_descr: Healthcare design projects require careful integration of spatial and structural requirements. Today, design teams typically resolve these requirements in two separate, largely sequential steps. In the first step, architects leverage their experience and vision to develop space plans that address program and goals. Next, based on the architect's recommended design, engineers generate and refine a structural design to address structural requirements. This manual process produces a very limited number of non-optimal spatial and structural design solutions with unclear decision rationale. This project presents an Integrated Spatial-Structural Optimization (ISSO) decision making methodology. ISSO supports design teams by helping them generate, analyze, and manage a vast number of integrated spatial and structural solutions. ISSO features a bi-level optimization workflow that has been customized for spatial and structural design of healthcare facilities. Our work describes implementation in the Autodesk's Dynamo parametric modeling platform, and retrospective validation of the algorithm and workflow on an industry case study to demonstrate how our model can help design teams quickly generate, analyze, and manage more conceptual design options.

proj_bullets: Category==Generative Design | Automated Service Core Generation | Automated space planning==Client==Autodesk, USA==Status==Autodesk Dynamo plugin written==Year==2015
proj_descr: Building design entails an intuitive and informative exploration of an architect involving iterative refinement of design ideas until client objectives, and priorities are satisfied. Similarly, service cores in a building are designed through the exploration of multifarious design options each with different performative metrics regarding accessibility, efficiency, cost, feasibility, etc. As the current process is labor-intensive, manual & dependent on the expertise of the architect, the search space leading to the selection of an optimal design alternative is very limited. This project describes Service Core Generator (SCG), a library in Autodesk Dynamo enabling automated generation of service core models for varied building shell geometry types (limited to orthogonal profiles). The tool described encodes explicit and implicit domain knowledge into the system, facilitating service core models for buildings across varied scale with varied use type's including offices, hotels, and residential buildings.

proj_bullets: Category==Spatial Analytics | Origin Destination Data | Web Application==Client== Georgia Tech, USA==Status==Masters project==Year==2015
proj_descr: The project addresses the issue of spatial mismatch of jobs and the accessibility to job locations based on different age, income and industry group. Taking Atlanta as a case study, we developed a geospatial analysis tool enabling developers, the city planning bureau and the residents to identify potential sites of redevelopment with better economic development opportunities. It also aids to find potential location to live with respect to users' choices for transit options, walkability, job location and proximity to chosen land use. We built our model on a block level in the city, imparting them a score, visualizing the data as a heat map. The metrics to compute the score included proximity to job, proximity to workers' residence, transit availability, walkability and number of landmark elements near the site. We worked with Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD) Data along with residence area characteristics (RAC) and work place area characteristic (WAC) data sets, where the total number of data-points was over 3 million. It was challenging for us to optimize computation such that the prototype performs statistical analysis and updates visualization in real time. The research further is prototyped as a web application leveraging Leaflets' Open Street Maps API and D3 visualization plugin. The research showed that there is a high degree of spatial mismatch between home and job locations with very few jobs with driving distance within 5 -10 miles with limited transit options in Atlanta. Further, it showed that low-earning workers need to travel significantly larger distance for work compared to higher class.

proj_bullets: Category==Responsive surfaces | Intelligent Facades | Interactive tangible systems==Client== Graduate work (under Prof. Jenny Sabin and Dr. Peter Lloyd Jones), Upenn, USA==Status==Published research==Year==2012
proj_descr: The fundamental processes in living systems can be a potential resource to derive nonlinear relationships that could find application in the design of responsive surface from an architectural standpoint. This research focuses on deriving a parametric relationship from a phenomenon in cell biology to generate an architectural expression of responsive surface/facade. It further delineates the dynamic feedback mechanism from the environment and user as control factors. Through extensive investigation of cell-to-cell connections in the mammary epithelial cells and review of evident relay of communication across the entire system of cells, we could unfold the logical parameters of the biological system. Parametric modelling indicating the causality of the surface condition, changes with the change in extracellular matrix. This gives an opportunity to manoeuvre the surface parameters, contrary to the involuntary cell environment where the behaviours are under the control of a physiological process. Architecturally, the dynamic relationship of surface in a hybridised model, explains that interactivity is not a mere one to one response to a stimulus. Evidently, this interactive process can be a sophisticated loop of feedback through different materiality and componentry that play their effects (and are played back) by active surfaces.

proj_bullets: Category==Gaming Device | Product design | Kids toys==Client== Georgia Tech, USA==Status==Protoyping and User study==Year==2014
proj_descr:
Through research, we observed that parents often are troubled when they go grocery shopping with their children. Kids become bored and irritated in these public places and they throw tantrums. This irritation wears down parents, and creates an undesirable experience for both the parent and the child.

In order to alleviate users' shopping experience, our goal was to create an engaging experience for children who visit grocery stores with their parents,. We brainstormed ten initial designs as a starting point for getting to a potential solution. Out of these, we narrowed down to three strong candidates whichseemed promising. We investigated each design from angles of cognitive, social, economical, anthropomorphic, and technological feasibility. From feedback and further refinement, we arrived at a final design - PIKNIK. Our idea was to design and prototype a recipe creation game. This application would be loaded on a colorful, ergonomic tablet, provided by the grocery store to empower kids to become a virtual chef. The tablets' interface would allow kids to scan grocery products from the store, view nutritional aspects of those products, and using these ingredients engage them in the shopping experience while they make their recipe. We set out to prototype this idea and further gather user feedback through evaluation. We prototyped our game on a tablet, and conducted user studies with kids between the age of 4-10. While both kids and their parents loved our idea and the initiative, we identified several usability issues in our initial prototype. Based on the feedback. we finally refined our prototype to develop the final version of the game.

proj_bullets: Category==Utensil Design | Artifact | Product design | Tea cup==Client==Bund Shanghai Initiative, China==Status==Design Entry==Year==2021
proj_descr:
Chinese culture has imbibed drinking tea for ages. Be it meeting between friends, families or professional business delegates. Drinking tea always has been a starting point of conversations, new relations and strengthening old ones. teaCUP is inspired from the beautiful and timeless monument to the People's Heroes sculpture situated at Shanghai Bund. The form not only resonates the monument but also imbibes in it similar qualities of strength, serenity, and unity. Functionally these tea cups can keep any liquid warm for longer hours like a thermos.  Thus, the presented artifacts are perfect for drinking warm tea for extended hours.
These utenisls can be built using ceramics, stainless steel coatings, or with colored glass. They can be varied in form and color to create variety yet preserving the design theme that implicitly resonates the People's Heroes monument.

proj_bullets: Category==Sculpture | Urban Park Retrofit | Place making==Client==San Jose Light House Trust, USA==Status==Design Entry==Year==2020
proj_descr:
San Jose is placed at the heart of Silicon Valley. It is a global magnet attracting ideas, talent, and investment motivated to improve peoples' lives. This is made possible by the exchange of ideas that includes people from diverse parts of the world with diverse experiences. Our design celebrates this notion of 'inclusivity', that is the life-blood of Silicon Valley. We present Pinnacle, a 185 ft high landmark structure built with light and durable carbon fiber reinforced polymer composites that provide a semi-shaded iconic space that is memorable and eventful. This structure represents inclusiveness, collaboration, and the notion of diversity that brings people together. Functionally it shades a sunken courtyard and a set of watchtowers. These spaces encourage people watching and public interaction. The watchtower allows users to experience the neighboring area of the site including the beautiful cityscape of San Jose from multiple levels (40 ft and 60 ft high).

The sunken court is adjoined by green grass mounds that inhabit spaces such as cafes, restaurants, bars, libraries, and interactive communal rooms (40k sqft area). The green mounds are designed to encourage outdoor sports activities such as running, hiking, biking, etc. More importantly, the sunken court is carefully designed to create a natural barrier between the interaction space and the natural riparian habitat that adjoins the site. Furthermore, we place a thick vegetative cover as a green park between the Guadalupe River and the sunken court to obstruct glare from artificial light at night. Our lighting design strategy places two kinds of light. The first is a LED strip channel lighting carefully encased in a carbon fiber reinforced polymer channel at the top of the Pinnacle. This design creates a continuous blue light source for diffused lighting at night, reducing glare and visual disturbance to the birds, insects, fishes, etc. The second light source is the LED spot lights placed on ground that is shielded by metal protectors and by the sunken courtyard's design. These lighting techniques allow the proposed space to be activated 18 hours a day and 7 days a week. Our proposed plan preserves the existing sculpture 'Five Skaters' in its original location near the N Autumn street. However, we propose to relocate the pool to two entry plazas as seen in our site plan. We further relocate the children's carousel and the tot-lot playground into the green vegetation area near the river.

proj_bullets: Category==Urban Design | Entertainment District | Place making==Client==Urban Land Institute (ULI), USA==Status==Shortlisted as top 4 (finalist) best entries==Year==2016==Team==With Yihan Wu, Shijia Huang, and Megan McMullen, Georgia Tech, USA
proj_descr:
Design proposal for the prestigious Urban Land Institute Design Competition. The site given was in midtown Atlanta, USA, where we proposed to redevelop it as an entertainment district which will be active 18 hours a day and 7 days of the week. We also proposed a collection of mixed use programs including, offices, high-end residences, affordable housing, retail spaces, banks, bars, shops, malls, cinemas and movie theater areas.

In theatre and film, the screen forms an imaginary fourth wall, separating the audience from the action within the fictitious world. Just as innovative thespians have broken the fourth wall to engage directly with their audience, the Stage Street design would break the fourth wall of Atlanta culture by blurring the boundaries of public and private spaces and inviting users to engage in a shared life. Elements such as plazas, balconies, rooftops, outdoor dining, a linear park, and event spaces create stages to see and be seen. Special attention was given to the ground floor of buildings, using a continuous street wall, facade transparency, activation, detailing, and variation to create an inviting pedestrian environment. The design uniquely blended entertainment industry, culture, and social spaces to create a dynamic, mixed-use development.

proj_bullets: Category==Complex Geometry | Non-linear design system | Prefabricated components==Client==Graduate Studio, Upenn, USA==Status==Masters Project==Year==2009

The design was formulated from a parametric module, design and developed in Autodesk's Maya software. Spatial arrangements were composed by intelligent juxtapostions and connections of a base parametric module. This gave rise to multiple design expressions alongwith volume enclosure possbilities that was able to accomodate one bedroom to duplex four bedroom units. Some modules supported a combination of inclined and flat floors. Flat floors were used for formal areas like living, bedroom, etc , while the inclined floors were used to house informal areas like gathering spaces, children play areas etc. Also, each of the unit had a roof garden that helped integrate the landscape into the building.

proj_bullets: Category==Energy Modeling | Form finding | Simulated Geometry==Client==Graduate work at Upenn, USA==Status==Masters project==Year==2009
proj_descr:
The goal of this project was to re-design the Levine building in Philadelphia, USA to enhance its energy efficiency and indoor comfort quality. Software used to test energy consumption and assess indoor comfort were Ecotect, Energy 10, Radiance, Lightscape, Flovent, VisualDoe, Energyplus, and DesignBuilder. The idea was s to design a L-shaped building so that it creates a courtyard on the southwest direction where, the incoming summer wind shall create natural ventilation. A steel louvered wall in the north-east direction blocked the uncomfortable winter wind.

Further, CFD analysis showed better wind circulation in and around the building due to the proposed design. CFD wind analysis of the existing site condition and its neighborhood was performed in the Flovent wind simulation software. It showed the attributes of wind in the neighborhood like, pressure variation temperature and viscoisty variation etc.The roof of the building was covered with Photo voltaic cells, to harness solar energy. Also the north and east facade were shielded with steel foldable louvres, that helped in gaurding the buiding from undesirable wind. The south-east courtyard contained a small water body, which drastically helped to cool down the hot summer micro climate of the building. It also acted as a leisure space for residents.

proj_bullets: Category==Furniture Design | Work desk | Work from home life | Toddlers' space==Client==Formica Form 2021==Status==Design Entry==Year==2021
proj_descr:
In the year 2020, the world faced a serious challenge, the COVID -19 pandemic. To maintain social hygiene, parents had to manage kids and at the same time had to work from home with the same diligence, as they would in an office setting. This created havoc for tele working parents with child-care responsibilities. In these testing times, we hypothesize that having a comfortable furniture, that addresses the need of caregiving and work will improve efficiency in parenting and ease in working from home ensuring increasing productivity. Owing to the need of a new working space, we present 'The Womb', a work desk that comes with added toddlers space where they can live and play. In this space, parents can place a crib for new born babies, or they can use it as a play area for kids between the age 1-5 years. This furniture allows parents to peacefully focus on work, while keeping a protective eye on their kids. Currently, lacking such a furniture, parents either have to sit on their computer with their kids or they make to and fro trips between their workplace and their designated kids area. We envision with 'The Womb', parents can better focus on work, while they know there kids are safe and secure, right next to them.

The furniture is of size 1775 mm x 1810 mm x 1700 mm (length, width, and height) making it a compact unit that can be placed in a living space or in a bedroom. In addition, the design accommodates ample flexibility in terms of visual and physical connection to allow kids privacy and the right set of parental care. For example, it comes with a removable fence to ensure kids stay at the toddlers' area. In addition, the work desk can be folded to allow increase in work space, or increase in visual connectivity to the toddlers' area (that also creates more open space for kids). Similarly, it is designed with vertical and horizontal louvers that creates an enclosure (which kids love), yet provides a visual connection to them such that parents can ensure they are safe and well protected.

proj_bullets: Category==Residences | Net Zero Building | Sustainable Design==Client==Perform Net Zero Trust==Status==Design Entry==Year==2016
proj_descr:
COMMUNITY
Embrace Zero, is an exemplary reflection to improve human life by providing an urban realm which ensures, community engagement, public interaction and an opportunity to seek and provide for everyone. Respecting the local guidelines of NC2-P40 zone, the proposed mixed use development employs public functions at the ground level, including street facing restaurants, cafes, and groceries, educational spaces including library, maker spaces and vocational training facilities. It provides bike storages encouraging biking around the neighborhood. Upper levels are revitalized by providing strategically located sky gardens and cantilevered semi sheltered spaces to enrich a diverse and intriguing spatial experience.

DESIGN
The upper blocks are up to 5 level high, composed of community spaces and residential apartments including studio (465 sqft), one bedroom (650 sqft) and two bedroom (900 sqft) apartments. They are designed to be compact and efficient, encouraging residents to spend leisure time outside with each other in the neighborhood. Reducing apartment size also ensures lower price range for the units, making it affordable for a larger population of the city. All living units allow natural ventilation by eliminating traditional double loaded corridor plan and introducing semi-open single loaded corridor system with operable screens. Operable windows on opposing sides of the unit allow free cross flow of air. The blocks maximize southern exposure to gain maximum passive solar gain and day lighting by orienting to the south and strategically stepping down for continued exposure. The envelope is tightly sealed and well-insulated, and thermal bridging is minimized. External vertical shutters across west and southern facade are opened during cool weather to take advantage of passive solar heat gains, and are closed during warmer weather, providing resident engagement and control while eliminating the need for a cooling system.

ENERGY
The PV arrays overhang the building to maximize the electricity generation. PV cells are covered in polychromatic glass laminate, which is highly efficient to capture and distribute daylight into covered courts. Hot water and space heating is ensured through a ground-source heat pump. Floors are heated and cooled via in-slab radiant conditioning supplied by heat pumps for increased occupant comfort. Leveraging high rainfall potential of the region, a rain water cistern of size 30 000 cubic feet is provided underneath the community garden to allow grey water reuse. We used nail laminated timber as the structural frame considering its best environmental performance with respect to global warming, environment acidification, ozone depletion, smog creation etc.

proj_bullets: Category==Automated analysis | Walkability analysis | Node edge data structure==Client==Collaborative Research==Status==Simaud 2018 full paper publication==Year==2019==Team==With Mathew Swartz, NJIT, USA
proj_descr: Through laser scanning, GIS data, new manufacturing methods, and complex designs, analysis of terrain in relation to human mobility is becoming ever more necessary.  While standards for wheelchair ramps exist, they rarely show the entire picture, nor do they account for surface variation beyond a single axis.  Although graph creation techniques in CAD exist for flat terrain, directional edge weights accounting for this variation are lacking.  In this paper, a summary of research from both biomechanics and architecture in relation to surface walkability is presented, followed by a review of creation methods for a searchable graph representing an environment in CAD.  A novel graph creation method that can respond to variations in surface height for walkability analysis is presented, where the edge weights of the graph are based on surface condition of parent-child height variations.

proj_bullets: Category==Master planning | Tourism district | Adaptive reuse==Client==With Vast Design LLC, Shanghai, China==Status==Design Development==Year==2012
proj_descr:
In the current urban structure of Shanghai, Xujiahui plays a key role as one of the central commercial hub. Nevertheless its commercial significance fails to impart any distinctive character to Xujiahui that would otherwise attract a big percentage of tourists as compared to other notable tourist spots in the city (Bund, Nanjing Road, People square). An initial study indicates that an incoherent delineation of public spaces is responsible for its failure to create an impactful urban space. The research outlines the existing fallacies in present urban design scenario and the process of finding appropriate design solutions that could be incorporated into urban planning guidelines to change lifestyles of people by changing their urban space.

Evaluations are made based on research inventory and successful existing urban design models of Bund and Nanjing road. The archaic architectural landmarks like church, museums and old libraries are rarely emphasized to create appealing public gathering spaces. Some are overshadowed by cluttered modern built forms in spaces that previously existed as plazas. The project addresses both macro and micro level variances in the urban design, potential sustainable solutions and related advancement in the policy making systems in the urban planning regulations of Xujiahui to elevate it to 4A level tourist spot. The research also analyses the causality between the planning reform in Xujiahui and possibility of increased revenue generation from tourism that would further impact development.

Image Source, Vast LLC, China.

Standard repetition has been replaced by custom variation. The Utopian city in the design concept gives importance to human interaction and community formation. Each unit in this utopian system is inspired from Cocoliths found in natural systems.

proj_descr:
A portion of the I-85 bridge in Atlanta, GA, USA (92FT) collapsed on 30th March 2017, leaving North and South bound traffic through GA disrupted. This research answered questions such as: (1) How did the collapse affect people?
(2) Were they more stressed than usual
during that period? (3) What were their coping mechanisms? (4) Were there differences in the
sentiments expressed by locals vs. those from other areas? The findings emphasize the
necessity of alternative transportation infrastructure to efficiently reroute traffic both local and from other areas going through
Atlanta when a major interstate is dysfunctional. Bike paths and street design conducive to safe biking is a necessity to deal with
travel disruptions. Social media analysis allows planners and policy makers to gauge peoples
experience during crisis. Reduce cost and time for analysis. The analysis captures specific nuances such as
people's perception and
preference during a crisis incident. This is often overlooked when dealing with
only traffic data. Most findings matched with the results available from traffic data . As such
social media can be considered a reliable source of data when used as an
alternative to enrich the finding of a crisis event.
